intro: Potentilla tabernaemontani subvar. parviflora, commonly known as the small-flowered cinquefoil, is a perennial shrub native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, woody stems covered in fine, silvery hairs. The plant produces small, bright yellow flowers that bloom in early summer, arranged in clusters of five, giving it its common name. Its leaves are compound, consisting of five oval-shaped leaflets, and are often covered in a soft, downy texture. This species is well adapted to rocky and arid environments, thriving in full sun and well-drained soils.
